page.title: List of Microsoft Visual Studio add-ins

revision.text:
<!-- IMPORTANT NOTE – READ BEFORE ADDING AN ENTRY This is a list of NOTABLE Microsoft Visual Studio add-ins, as judged by Wikipedia's notability policies, obtained by searching Wikipedia for WP:N. Please don't add external links or wikilinks to nonexistent articles – instead, read our notability policies and write the article first, ensuring to demonstrate notability. Microsoft Visual Studio add-ins without articles, redlinks, external links, and links to articles that aren't Microsoft Visual Studio add-ins will be pruned periodically. Important note ends. --> {{Dynamic list}} The following is a list of '''notable Microsoft Visual Studio Add-ins'''. Add-ins are [[computer software|software products]] designed to be used in conjunction with and extend [[Microsoft Visual Studio]]. There are many [[Software versioning|versions]] of Microsoft Visual Studio, so some of these products may not be compatible with all versions of the product. Managed add-ins are typically found in the following location on Windows Vista and higher: C:\Users\{username}\Documents\Visual Studio {version}\Addins. [[Component Object Model|COM]]-based add-ins can be installed anywhere as their directories are specified via the [[Windows Registry|registry]].
==IDE add-ins==
===Source control support=== *[[AnkhSVN]] – Provides a free [[Subversion (software)|Subversion]] client for Visual Studio *[[VisualSVN]] - Subversion integration for Visual Studio 2003/2005/2008/2010/2012/2013/2015/2017 *VsTortoise - A free [[TortoiseSVN]] add-in for Microsoft Visual Studio 2008/2010/2012/2013
===Refactoring and productivity=== *[[CodeRush]] - Refactoring and productivity plugin *[[Visual Assist X]] - Productivity plugin, like Resharper. Notable for C++ support
===Other=== *[[PVS-Studio]] - Static Code Analyzer for C#,C,C++,C++11,C++/CX. Supports Visual Studio 2005/2008/2010/2012/2013/2015/2017. *[[Designbox]] - Adds a toolbox that lets you associate initial property values with controls *[[Koders]] – Adds a search plug-in to search the [[Koders]] database *[[.NET Reflector|Reflector]] - a code browsing utility *[[Dotfuscator]] – Provides tools to help prevent [[reverse engineering]] *[[VSdocman]] - Visual Studio code commenter (XML doc comments) and API documentation generator. For VS 2010/2008/2005/2003/2002. *[[XMLSpy]] – Integrates the XMLSpy IDE into Visual Studio for editing XML, XSLT, XSD, XQuery, XBRL, OOXML, etc. *[[Liquid XML Studio]] – Integrates Liquid XML Tools: XML Schema Editor, WSDL Editor, XPath Expression Builder, and Web Services Test Client into Visual Studio 2005/2008/2010
==Language add-ins== *[[Ada programming language]] *[[ActionScript|ActionScript 3]], for building Flash applications *[[Boo (programming language)|Boo programming language]] *[[Eiffel (programming language)|Eiffel programming language]] *[[F Sharp (programming language)|F# programming language]] *[[Oxygene (programming language)|Oxygene programming language]] *[[Python Tools for Visual Studio]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Microsoft Visual Studio|Add-ins]] [[Category:Microsoft lists|Visual Studio Add-ins]]

page.title: List of buildings in Laredo, Texas

revision.comment: rename image for the corresponding image on commons
revision.text:
[[Image:San Agustin Cathedral.JPG|thumb|300px|right|The San Agustin Cathedral]]This is a list of the tallest and largest buildings in [[Laredo, Texas]]. Laredo is the county seat and most populated city in [[Webb County]], [[Texas]]. The city has over 230,000 residents and there are over 730,000 residents in the [[Laredo-Nuevo Laredo Metropolitan Area]].
==Tallest buildings== [[Image:Former Hamilton Hotel in Laredo, TX IMG 1766.JPG|thumb|Hamilton Hotel]] [[Image:Rio Grande Plaza Hotel.jpg|thumb|right|Rio Grande Plaza Hotel]] [[Image:Holiday Inn Laredo.JPG|thumb|right|The Holiday Inn]] [[Image:Laredo Medical Center.JPG|thumb|right|The Laredo Medical Center]] [[Image:Walker Plaza -Laredo.jpg|thumb|Walker Plaza]] [[Image:Mall del Norte NW.JPG|thumb|right|[[Mall del Norte]]]] [[Image:Rio Grande Republic Capitol.jpg|thumb|right|Today a part of the Republic of the Rio Grande's Capitol building is used as a museum.]] [[Image:Webb County Courthouse (1905).jpg|thumb|right|Webb County Courthouse in 1905]] [[Image:Webb County Courthouse 2007.jpg|Webb COunty Courthouse in 2007|thumb|right]]
===Hamilton Hotel=== The '''Hamilton Hotel''' was built in 1900 as a three-story building. Beginning in 1923 an additional 9 floors were constructed, to plans by the prominent San Antonio architect Atlee B Ayres and his son Robert, making it the tallest building in [[Laredo, Texas]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/ci/bu/?id=102906 |publisher=Emporis.com |title=Buildings of Laredo |accessdate=2009-08-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929160041/http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/ci/bu/?id=102906 |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }}</ref> Today it serves as an apartment complex at 815 Salinas St, in downtown Laredo. It is {{convert|151|ft|m}} tall and has 12 floors (above ground). In 1992 it was included in the National Register of Historic Places.<ref name="nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com">[http://www.nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com/tx/Webb/state.html National Register of Historic Places]</ref> After renovation and repair, it won the Housing and Urban Development [[Award for Excellence in Historic Preservation]] in 2002.<ref>[http://www.huduser.org/research/histwin2002.html Housing and Urban Development] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120801202636/http://www.huduser.org/research/histwin2002.html |date=2012-08-01 }}</ref>
===San Agustin Cathedral=== The '''[[San Agustin Cathedral]]''' (formerly the San Agustin Church) was built in 1778 as a small parish by the Bishop of Guadalajara. In 1866, work began to turn the small parish into a large church. San Agustin Church is a Gothic structure with a five-story- 141 ft (43m) [[bell tower|bell]] / [[clock tower]]. All the windows have the traditional Gothic shape with [[stained glass]] located between structural bays of its masonry walls. A French priest, Father Pierre Yves Keralum, was the designer and architect for this historical monument. The new church was opened on December 12, 1872.<ref>[http://www.dioceseoflaredo.org/html/san_agustin.html Diocese of Laredo; San Agustin Church History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927235610/http://www.dioceseoflaredo.org/html/san_agustin.html |date=2007-09-27 }}</ref>
===Rio Grande Plaza=== The '''Rio Grande Plaza'''<ref>[http://www.venturastreet.com/RioGrandePlaza/ Rio Grande Plaza Homepage]</ref> (formerly the Hilton Hotel) is an independently owned hotel located on the banks of the [[Rio Grande]]. It was built in 1975 and is 15 floors high. Its within a walking distance from the [[Gateway to the Americas International Bridge]] and has a view of the Rio Grande, [[Nuevo Laredo]], [[Mexico]], and downtown Laredo
===Ramada Plaza - Laredo=== The '''Ramada Plaza - Laredo ''' is a hotel affiliated to the [[Wyndham Hotel Group]]chain of hotels. Its building is the fourth tallest building in Laredo. Construction started in mid 1982 & opened its doors in late 1983 and it is 14 floors high. It first opened its door as a Holiday Inn. It is located along [[Interstate 35]] south near the Laredo Civic Center. The Ramada Plaza - Laredo serves as a full service hotel which includes shuttle service, bar, restaurant, fitness center, business center, and outside pool. Fun fact: current General Manager Laura Bailey has devoted her life employed at this hotel since its opened in 1983.
===BBVA Compass Bank Building (Formerly Laredo National Bank Headquarters)=== The '''Laredo National Bank Headquarters'''<ref>[http://www.lnb.com/ Laredo National Bank Homepage]</ref> building was built in 1926 and it served as the Robert E. Lee Hotel briefly. Two additional floors were added and it became known as the Plaza Hotel until 1980. In 1981 it was purchased by the [[Laredo National Bank]], renovated, and converted in 1982 to the bank's headquarters. In 2008 [[BBVA Compass]] Bank acquired LNB, and the handsome building is still in use as a bank today. At 10 stories, it is the fifth tallest in the city.
===Senior Citizens Home=== The Laredo's '''Senior Citizen Home''' is located in the San Agustin Historical District across from the Hamilton Hotel. The building is sixth tallest building in Laredo with 8 floors above ground. It serves the Laredo area as a retirement home for the senior citizens.
===Laredo Medical Center=== The '''Laredo Medical Center'''<ref>[http://www.laredomedical.com/body.cfm?id=13 Laredo Medical Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070702174226/http://www.laredomedical.com/body.cfm?id=13 |date=2007-07-02 }}</ref> (Formally the Mercy Hospital) was built in 1999. It is the largest medical center in the Laredo area. Its building is located on [[United States Route 59]] and is 7 floors high. It is of Spanish Colonial architecture. It has 325 licensed beds and 180 active physicians. The hospital has 1,568 employees. Its services include:
===Gateway Inn=== The '''Gateway Inn''' is an independent hotel in the Laredo area. It is located along [[Business Spur Interstate 35]] south. It is six stories high and it is located near [[Mall del Norte]].
===Rialto Hotel=== The '''Rialto Hotel'''<ref>[http://www.rialto-hotel.com/ Rialto Hotel Homepage]</ref> (formerly the Sames Moore Building) was built in 1925 and was used as a Local car dealership headquarters. In 2005 the building was bought and was renovated and turned into a hotel. It is the 9th tallest building in Laredo and is 6 stories high. It is located across the Hamilton Hotel in downtown San Agustin Historical District.
===Walker Plaza=== The '''Walker Plaza''', named after rancher [[Gene S. Walker, Sr.]], was built in 1995 and houses the headquarters of the [[South Texas National Bank]]. It is 5 floors high and is the 10th tallest building in Laredo. The building is located along [[Interstate 35]] south. On May 21, 1996 the building was a victim of a bomb blast which caused minor damage to the north side of the building.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C05E6DC1039F932A15756C0A960958260 NY Times report on Walker Plaza Blast]</ref> This explosion caused all the federal buildings in [[Texas]], [[Oklahoma]], [[Arkansas]], [[Louisiana]] and [[New Mexico]] to be placed on "tighten security".<ref>[http://archive.southcoasttoday.com/daily/05-96/05-21-96/1bomb.htm South Coast Today article on the Walker Plaza]</ref>
==Largest Building== '''[[Mall Del Norte]]'''<ref>[http://www.malldelnorte.com/shop/malldelnorte.nsf/index Mall del Norte Homepage] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070813023412/http://www.malldelnorte.com/shop/malldelnorte.nsf/index |date=2007-08-13 }}</ref> is a [[Shopping mall#Super regional|super regional shopping mall]] in Laredo. The mall opened in 1977 and has since been renovated in 1991, 1993 (expansion), and 2007. It is located along [[Interstate 35]] in the city's rapidly growing retail hub the city. Mall Del Norte is {{convert|1198199|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}.; with 148 stores, making it the second largest mall in [[South Texas]] and the largest building in Laredo.
==National Register of Historical Places== List of National Register of Historical Places<ref name="nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com"/> in the Laredo area.
===Hamilton Hotel=== The '''Hamilton Hotel''' was first constructed in 1900 and was expanded from a three-story building to a 12-story building in various phases during 1924 to 1949. Robert M. Ayres was the buildings architect and Atlee B. Ayres was its engineer. The building is of Mission/Spanish Revival architectural style.
===San Agustin Cathedral=== {{main article|San Agustin Cathedral}}
===Republic of the Rio Grande Capitol Building=== '''[[Republic of the Rio Grande Capitol Building Museum|Republic of the Rio Grande Capitol Building]]'''<ref>[http://www.webbheritage.org/riograndehistory.htm Republic of the Rio Grande Museum Home Page] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100122101431/http://www.webbheritage.org/riograndehistory.htm |date=2010-01-22 }}</ref> is located in the downtown historical district next to the historical La Posada Hotel. It was once the [[Republic of the Rio Grande]] Capitol building now showcases memorabilia from the short lived Republic of the Rio Grande. It displays pictures, books, and furniture from the 19th century Laredo area. It offers guided tours for school age children and adults year-round. Because of this Republic, Laredo had flown seven flags instead of the traditional Six Flags over Texas.
===Laredo Federal Building=== '''Laredo Federal Building''' was finished in 1907. It is by the architect [[James Knox Taylor]] and is of [[Classical Revival]] style. In the early 20th century the building was used as a Courthouse, Customhouse, Government Office, and Post Office. Today it is used for federal offices and the 78040 Post Office.
===Webb County Courthouse=== The [[Webb County Courthouse (Texas)|Webb County Courthouse]] was built in 1909 in downtown Laredo. Since its inauguration it has served as the Webb County courthouse. The cornerstone gives H. Sparbert as the contractor and the renowned Albert Giles of San Antonio as the architect.
===Fort McIntosh=== '''[[Fort McIntosh (Texas)|Fort McIntosh]]''' was an army base built in Laredo in 1850. Most of the fort's buildings are of Late Victorian architectural style. Today, Fort McIntosh was absorbed by the Laredo Community College. All the buildings were renovated and repaired and serve as classrooms and offices.
{{wide image|Fort McIntosh U.S. Military Reservation 1892.JPG|800px|align-cap=center|''The full length of the Fort McIntosh U.S. Military Reservation in 1892.''}}
==Proposed/Under Construction Buildings== {| class="wikitable" ! Building Name!! Status !! Type !! Use !! Floors !! Height ! Area ! Opening Year ! page.title: List of names of Asian cities in different languages

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=April 2009}} This is a '''list of cities in [[Asia]]''' that have several '''different names in different languages''', including former names. Many cities have different names in different languages. Some cities have also undergone [[Geographical renaming|name changes]] for political or other reasons. This article does not offer any opinion about what the "original", "official", "real", or "correct" name of any city is or was. Cities are listed alphabetically by their '''current best-known name in English'''. The English version is followed by variants in other languages, in alphabetical order by name including any historical variants and former names. Foreign names that are the same as their English equivalents may be listed. ''Note: The blue asterisks generally indicate the availability of a Wikipedia article in that language for that city; it also provides additional reference for the equivalence. Red asterisks or a lack of an asterisk indicate that no such article exists, and that these equivalents without further footnotes should be viewed with caution.'' __NOTOC__ {{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}} ==A== {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:100px;"| English Name ! Other names or former names |- | [[Abakan]] | '''Ağban''' - Ағбан (Khakass),{{listref|KNAB}} '''Ábāhām''' - 阿巴坎 (Cantonese), '''Abakan''' - Абакан (Russian), '''Abakan''' - '''アバカン''' (Japanese), '''Ābākǎn''' - 阿巴坎 (traditional and simplified characters) (Mandarin Chinese), '''Ust’-Abakanskoe''' - Усть-Абаканское (former Russian, pre–1931){{listref|KNAB}}, '''{{lang|ur|{{nq|اباکان}}}}''' (Urdu), அபாக்கன் (Tamil) |- | [[Aleppo]] | '''Alep''' (Catalan[[:ca:Alep|*]], Croatian[[:sh:Alep|*]], French[[:fr:Alep|*]], Romanian[[:ro:Alep|*]], Slovene[[:sl:Alep|*]]), '''Alep''' - ''Алеп'' (Serbian)[[:sr:Алеп|*]], '''Alepas''' (Lithuanian)[[:lt:Alepas|*]], '''Alepo''' (Basque[[:eu:Alepo|*]], Esperanto[[:eo:Alepo|*]], Galician[[:gl:Alepo|*]], Spanish[[:es:Alepo|*]]), '''Ālèpō''' - 阿勒颇 (simplified characters) / 阿勒頗 (traditional characters) (Chinese)[[:zh:阿勒颇|*]], '''Alepo''' or '''Haleba''' (Latvian)[[:lv:Alepo|*]], '''Alepo''' or '''Ḩalab''' (Estonian)[[:et:Ḩalab|*]], '''Alepo''' or '''Aleppo''' (Portuguese)[[:pt:Alepo|*]], '''Aleppo''' (Breton[[:br:Aleppo|*]], Czech[[:cs:Aleppo|*]], Danish[[:da:Aleppo|*]], Dutch[[:nl:Aleppo|*]], Finnish[[:fi:Aleppo|*]], German[[:de:Aleppo|*]], Indonesian[[:id:Aleppo|*]], Italian[[:it:Aleppo|*]], Norwegian [Bokmål][[:no:Aleppo|*]], Polish[[:pl:Aleppo|*]], Swedish[[:sv:Aleppo|*]], Welsh[[:cy:Aleppo|*]]), '''Aleppó''' (Hungarian)[[:hu:Aleppó|*]], '''Aleppo''' - '''アレッポ''' (Japanese)[[:ja:アレッポ|*]], '''Ash-Shahbā’''' (lit., "the gray one") - {{lang|ar|الشهباء}} (Arabic [rare]),{{listref|KNAB}} '''Beroea''' (Latin)[[:la:Beroea (Syria)|*]],{{listref|KNAB}} '''Chalépio'''('''n''') - Χαλέπιο(ν) (Greek),{{listref|KNAB}} '''Hadad''' / '''Halab''' (Syriac), '''Halab''' (Uzbek), '''Ḥalab''' - {{lang|ar|حلب}} (Arabic[[:ar:حلب|*]],{{listref|KNAB}} Ottoman Turkish), '''Halab''' - ''Ҳалаб'' (Tajik)[[:tg:Вилояти Ҳалаб|*]], '''H̱aleb''' - ''Φιλαδέλφεια'' (Greek [archaic]), '''Rabbat Ammon''' - {{Hebrew|רבת עמון}} (Hebrew), 安曼 (Mandarin Chinese), ამანი (Georgian), అమ్మాన్ (Telugu), अम्मान (Marathi), அம்மான் (Tamil), '''{{lang|ur|{{nq|عمّان}}}}''' (Urdu) |- | [[Ankara]] | '''Aṁkārā'''' - అంకారా (Telugu), '''Ancara''' (Galician, Portuguese), '''Ancyra''' (Latin), '''Ăng-kā-lá''' - 安卡拉 (Mindong), '''Angora''' (former English, former Italian, former Romanian, former French), '''Ángyra''' - Άγκυρα (Greek), '''Ángyra''' - Ἄγκυρα (Ancient Greek), '''Ānkǎlā''' - 安卡拉 (Mandarin Chinese), '''Ankara''' - Անկարա (Armenian), '''Ankara''' - Анкара (Abkhaz, Russian, Serbian), '''Ankara''' - ანკარა (Georgian), '''Ankara''' - '''アンカラ''' (Japanese), '''Ānḳarah''' - آنقره (Ottoman Turkish), Anqara (Zazaki), '''Änqarä''' - Әнкарә (Tatar),{{listref|KNAB}} '''Ankaro''' (Esperanto), '''Anqara''' (Azeri, Uzbek), '''Änq̇ara''' - Аьнкьара (Lak), '''Anqarah''' - {{lang|ar|أنقرة}} (Arabic), '''Aqqara'''/'''Atqara''' (Inuktitut), '''Enqere''' (Kurdish), '''Enqere''' - ئه‌نقه‌ره (Uyghur), '''Ngōnkālā''' - 安卡拉 (Cantonese), '''{{lang|ur|{{nq|انقرہ}}}}''' (Urdu), அங்காரா (Tamil) |- | [[Antioch]] | '''Anniukkia''' (Inuktitut), '''Anţākīyah''' {{lang|ar|أنطاكيا}} (Arabic), '''Antakya''' (Azeri, Turkish[[:tr:Antakya, Hatay|*]]), '''Antioch-on-the-Orontes''' (extended name in English), '''Antioch''' (Scottish Gaelic), '''Antioche''' (French)[[:fr:Antioche|*]], '''Antiocheia''' - Ἀντιόχεια (Ancient Greek),{{listref|KNAB}} '''Antiochia''' (Hungarian[[:hu:Antiochia|*]], Interlingua, Latin, Slovak), '''Antiochia''' or '''Antiochia/Antioch/Antiochien am Orontes''' (German)[[:de:Antiochia am Orontes|*]], '''Antiochia''' or '''Antiochia di Siria''' (Italian)[[:it:Antiochia di Siria|*]], '''Antiochia''' or '''Antiochia Syryjska''' (Polish)[[:pl:Antiochia Syryjska|*]], '''Antiochia''' or '''Antiochia vid Orontes''' (Swedish)[[:sv:Antiochia vid Orontes|*]], '''Antióchia''' - ''Αντιόχεια'' (Greek), '''Antióchia i epí Dáfni''' - ''Αντιόχεια η επί Δάφνη'' / '''Antióchia i epí Oróntu''' - ''Αντιόχεια η επί Ορόντου'' / '''Antióchia i Megáli''' - ''Αντιόχεια η Μεγάλη'' (extended names in Greek), '''Antiochie''' (Czech)[[:cs:Antiochie|*]], '''Antiochië''' (Dutch)[[:nl:Antiochië|*]], '''Antiohia''' (Romanian), '''Antiohija''' (Croatian, Bosnian), '''Antiohija''' - Baudrand, ''Novum lexicon geographicum'', tomus primus, Isenaci, 1677, p. 272][https://books.google.ru/books?id=_sgh4g_MHKAC&pg=PA235&dq=Tobolfca&hl=ru&ei=2Mc-TeWBDOqW4gbeoZCuCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=Tobolfca&f=false ''Acta eruditorum ... '', p. 235] '''Tobolscum''' (Latin),[https://books.google.ru/books?id=YzHCDQBuxiwC&pg=PT269&dq=Tobolfcum&hl=ru&ei=FMY-TZXzIISWOoTXqNcK&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Tobolfcum&f=false H. ''; , p. 437] '''Tobolsk''' (French[[:fr:Tobolsk|*]], German[[:de:Tobolsk|*]], Polish[[:pl:Tobolsk|*]], Spanish[[:fr:Tobolsk|*]]) '''Tobol’sk''' – {{lang|ru|Тобольск}} (Russian),{{listref|KNAB}} '''Tobol’s’k''' – {{lang|uk|Тобольськ}} (Urkrainian[[:uk:Тобольськ|*]]), '''Toboļska''' (Latvian[[:lv:Toboļska|*]]),{{listref|KNAB}} '''Toborisuku''' – {{lang|ja|トボリスク}} (Japanese[[:ja:Toborisuku|*]]), '''Tubıl''' – {{lang|tt|Тубыл}} (Bashkir[[:ba:Тубыл (ҡала))|*]], Kazan Tatar[[:tt:Тубыл|*]]{{listref|KNAB}}), '''Tuōbóěrsīkè''' – {{lang|zh|托博爾斯克}} (Mandarin Chinese[[:zh:托博爾斯克|*]]), '''Tūpel ūs''' – {{lang|mns|Тӯпел ӯс}} (Mansi){{listref|KNAB}} |- | [[Tokyo]] | '''Dokyo''' - page.title: List of political parties in French Polynesia

revision.comment: +[[Category:Lists of political parties in France]]; +[[Category:Lists of political parties in Oceania]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Politics of French Polynesia}} This article lists '''[[political party|political parties]] in [[politics of French Polynesia|French Polynesia]]'''. French Polynesia has a [[two-party system]], which means that there are two dominant political parties, with extreme difficulty for anybody to achieve electoral success under the banner of any other party.
==Party-alliances in the elections on May 23, 2004 and by-elections on February 13, 2005==
Pro-independence-coalition *Union for Democracy (''Union pour la Démocratie'') (May 23, 2004: 27 seats; February 13, 2005: 27 seats) ** [[Aia Api]] (''New Land'') ** [[Here Ai'a]] (''Love of the Land'') ** [[Tavini Huiraatira]] (''People's servant'') ** [[Tapura Amui No Raromatai]] ** [[Tapura Amui No Te Faatereraa Manahune – Tuhaa Pae]] *Alliance for a New Democracy (''Alliance pour une Démocratie Nouvelle'') (May 23, 2004: 2 seats; February 13, 2005: 3 seats) ** [[Fetia Api]] (''New Star'') ** [[No Oe E Te Nunaa]] (''This Country Is Yours'') Conservative coalition (consisting of one party only): pro-autonomy, anti-independence *Popular Rally (May 23, 2004: 28 seats; February 13, 2005: 27 seats) ** [[Tahoera'a Huiraatira]] (''Popular Rally'')
==The parties== <!--:''The general rule on naming applies. That means: the parties are named in the English translation and the original native name is placed on the first line of the article unless the native form is more commonly used in English than the English form. Rationale and specifics: See: [[Wikipedia:Naming conventions (use English)]]''.-->
*[[Aia Api]] (''New Land'') *[[Fetia Api]] (''New Star'') *[[Here Ai'a]] (''Love of the Land'') *[[No Oe E Te Nunaa]] (''This Country Is Yours'') *[[Tahoera'a Huiraatira]] (''Popular Rally'') *[[Tavini Huiraatira]] (''People's Servant'') *[[Tapura Amui No Raromatai]] *[[Tapura Amui No Te Faatereraa Manahune - Tuhaa Pae]]
==See also== * [[List of political parties by country]]
{{French Polynesia topics}} {{French Polynesian political parties}} {{Oceania in topic|List of political parties in}}
[[Category:Lists of political parties by country|French Polynesia]] [[Category:Political parties in French Polynesia| ]] [[Category:French Polynesia-related lists|Political parties]] [[Category:Lists of political parties in France|+Polynesia]] [[Category:Lists of political parties in Oceania|French Polynesia]]

page.title: List of renamed places in the Gambia

revision.text:
This is a '''list of renamed places in [[the Gambia]]'''. * Bathurst → [[Banjul]] (1973)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accessgambia.com/information/banjul-history.html|title=History of Banjul|author=|date=|publisher=Accessgambia.com|accessdate=2012-10-29}}</ref> * Georgetown → [[Janjanbureh, The Gambia|Janjanbureh]] * James Island → [[Kunta Kinteh Island]] (2011)<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/03/africa/kunta-kinteh-island/index.html|title=The fight to save Kunta Kinteh island|last=Monks|first=Kieron|date=|work=CNN|access-date=2018-01-02|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> * [[MacCarthy Island]] → [[Janjanbureh Island]] (1995)
== See also == * [[Lists of renamed places]]

page.title: List of social nudity places in Asia

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=July 2010}} {{Portal|Nudity}} This '''list of social nudity places in Asia''' is a [[list of places where social nudity is practised]] for recreation in [[Asia]]. It includes free beaches (or clothing-optional beaches or [[nude beaches]]) and some resorts.
==China== *Dadonghai Beach, north end, in [[Sanya]], [[Hainan Island]]. This beach had been an unofficial naturist site for more than ten years before nudity at the beach was banned in February 2014 following complaints.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/10623731/Chinese-police-order-nudists-to-cover-up.html |title=Chinese police order nudists to cover up |publisher=The Telegraph |date=2014-02-07 |accessdate=2014-03-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iy-46VWUhM4 |title=Chinese nudists wrestle with beach ban |publisher=China View TV |date=2014-03-03 |accessdate=2014-03-13}}</ref>
==Hong Kong== [[File:NideHongKong.jpg|right|thumb|[[Hong Kong]], 10 km West from Airport, y.2006.]] [[File:Nudism Hong Kong.jpg|thumb|Kau Ling Chung beach.]] [[Hong Kong]] does not officially allow nude or topless bathing, and most local bathers are quite conservative in their beach dress (e.g. many women wear T-shirts over swimsuits). Nevertheless, more remote parts of Hong Kong's extensive coastline do offer opportunities for nudity: *At least one naturist organization in the territory arranges weekend boat trips to the more remote parts of [[Sai Kung]] Country Park in the [[New Territories]]. *Unofficial nudist beaches reportedly exist on [[Lantau Island]]. *Tai Long Wan beach on the [[Chi Ma Wan Peninsula]] is sometimes used by naturists. *Historically, nudists gathered at [[Sha Tin]] in the 1930s and [[Wok Tai Wan]] on [[Tsing Yi Island]], from the late 1930s to the 1950s. *Power Station Beach on [[Lamma Island]] is reported to be used for nude night swimming at times. *[[South Bay, Hong Kong|South Bay]] Beach near [[Repulse Bay]]. Some report that the beach is frequently used by groups of [[expatriate]] women for nude sunbathing [unconfirmed]. South Bay and neighboring [[Middle Bay (Hong Kong)|Middle Bay]] see occasional topless use by women. *Kau Ling Chung beach (狗嶺涌營地) – east of Fan Lau beach and due west of the obelisk is used by naturists. It is a remote location, usually empty except for the naturists.
==India== [[File:Naga baba.jpg|thumb|right|Naga mystics]] *Among the [[Hindu]] religious sects, only the sect known as [[Naga sadhu]] can be seen nude. These [[Sadhu]]s usually wear a [[loin cloth]] around their waist, but not always. They usually remain in their [[Akhara]], deep forest or isolation and come out in public only once every sixth year during [[Ardha Kumbh]] and [[Kumbha Mela]]. The Naga sadhus are prominent at [[Kumbha Mela]] and may not wear any clothes even in severe winter.
==Indonesia== *Bali au Naturel ([[Singaraja]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baliaunaturel.com/ |title=Bali au Naturel |date= |accessdate=2016-02-09}}</ref> *Laki Uma Villa ([[Denpasar]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naturistdirectory.com/Indonesia/611/Laki-Uma-Villa |title=Laki Uma Villa |publisher=Naturistdirectory.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-16}}</ref>
==Israel== *Neve Midbar Beach at the northern end of the [[Dead Sea]] is a small private resort with a section of the shore set aside as a nude beach.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dare to bare: 15 of the world's best nude beaches|url=https://edition.cnn.com/travel/article/best-nude-beaches-world/index.html|date=19 June 2018|author=Joe Yogerst|work=CNN Travel}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nevemidbar-beach.com/site/index.asp?lat=en|title=חוף נווה מדבר – main|publisher=|accessdate=25 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141106062858/http://www.nevemidbar-beach.com/site/index.asp?lat=en|archive-date=2014-11-06|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *Metsoke Dragot Beach by the [[Dead Sea]], located {{coord|31.579451|35.412648|format=dms|display=inline}} an oasis in the dead sea where a couple of sweet water springs pour into the [[Dead Sea]]. This is a natural beach and there are no facilities, but the sweet water springs can be used for shower after a dip in the dead sea.<ref name="acti_floa">{{Cite web | title = Floating in the Dead Sea | author = | work = Active Naturists | date = 20 February 2011 | accessdate = 2016-03-23 | url = http://activenaturists.net/2011/02/20/floating-in-the-dead-sea/ | quote = }}</ref> *Twice a year, in June and September, a mostly-young naturist festival is held in Israel, featuring a lot of parties, music, spiritual lessons, and more. This event takes place not far from [[Eilat]] on road number 40, at a place called "Desert Ashram".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.desertashram.co.il/Default.aspx?tabid=70|title=Welcome to the Ashram in the desert|publisher=Desertashram.co.il|accessdate=2015-08-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205182007/http://desertashram.co.il/Default.aspx?tabid=70|archive-date=2009-02-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==Japan== *Some public hot spring baths in [[Japan]] allow mixed gender nudity, particularly those in rural locations and where permitted by [[prefectures of Japan|prefectural]] law. Related Japanese terms include: ''[[onsen]]'' for hot spring; ''konyoku'' for mixed gender bath; and ''[[sentō]]'' for a type of public bath, but gender separated.
==Kyrgyzstan== The village of [[Kaji-Say]] has a beach with a section for nudists<ref>{{cite web|url=https://foursquare.com/v/nude-beach/50249096e4b0a32dd831ba9f |title=Nude Beach - Kadzhi Say vil., Ysyk-Köl |publisher=Foursquare.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-16}}</ref>
==Philippines== *China Sea Island in [[Boayan Island]], [[Philippines]]<ref>[http://netnude.com/main/info/fareast/index.html "Reports and Information - Asia/Pacific"]. Net Nude. Retrieved on September 1, 2014.</ref> *Fridays Island in [[El Nido, Palawan]], [[Philippines]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naturistholiday.info/Philippines/702/China_Sea_Island.aspx |title=Friday Island Paradise |publisher=Naturistholiday.info |date= |accessdate=2013-04-22}}</ref><ref>[http://www.malapacao.com/ "Home"]. Fridays Island. Retrieved on September 1, 2014.</ref> *Finca Granja is a proposed nudist resort, intended to be the first on the main island of the Philippines, located just outside [[Cauayan, Isabela|Cauayan]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Finca Granja Cauayan – a new naturist resort in the Phillippines|url=https://thailandnaturist.com/newsroom/finca-granja-cauayan-a-new-naturist-resort-in-the-phillippines/|author=Gregers Moller|date=21 April 2018|website=Naturist Association Thailand}}</ref>
==South Korea== {{unsourced section|date=July 2018}} *Nude [[forest bathing]] is a well-known traditional form of legalized nudism in Korea for well-being, in which nudists are allowed to walk through the trees in the park naked. Famous legal place include [[Jangheung County]] in [[South Jeolla Province]], [[South Korea]]. *Public baths (''[[Jjimjilbang]]'') are also widespread and nude [[communal bath]]ing is normal, although nudity is not permitted in unisex areas. *The government of [[Jeju Province]] has reviewed the opening of its first nude beaches – Jungmun Beach and Hamdeok Beach in [[Jeju Island]].
==Thailand== * In Thailand there are a number of naturist resorts. Many are member resorts of Naturist Association Thailand and host regularly scheduled monthly meetings. Examples include Chan Resort in [[Pattaya]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ChanResort.com|title=Chan Resort – Most Naturist Friendly Resort in Thailand|publisher=|accessdate=25 December 2014}}</ref> Oriental Village in [[Chiang Mai]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orientalvillage-chiangmai.com|title=Oriental Village Naturist Resort in Thailand – Chiang Mai|work=OrientalVillage|accessdate=25 December 2014}}</ref> Phuan Naturist Village outside of [[Sattahip]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://PhuanNaturistVillage.com/|title=Phuan Naturist Village|author=|date=|website=PhuanNaturistVillage.com}}</ref> Lemon Tree Resort in [[Phuket]], Barefeet in [[Bangkok]], and NF Camp in [[Phetchaburi]].<ref>{{cite web|website=Naturist Association Thailand|url=https://thailandnaturist.com/naturist-resorts/|title=Naturist Resorts}}</ref> Additional naturist resorts are under construction, including Peace Blue Naiharn in Phuket and The Oriental Beach Village on the island of Koh Kho Khao.<ref>{{cite web|title=Getting Naked In Thailand|url=http://www.nakedwanderings.com/blog/2018/03/29/getting-naked-thailand/|author=Nick&Lins|date=29 March 2018|website=Naked Wanderings}}</ref>
==Vietnam== *Gia Long Waterfall in [[Krông Ana District]], [[Đắk Lắk Province]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Get Naked: Top (And Topless) Places In Asia to Bare It All|url=http://magazine.tripzilla.com/top-nude-places-asia-bare-it-all/22736|website=TripZilla|date=25 June 2015|author=Jerlyn Ng}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{nudity}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Social nudity places in Asia}} [[Category:Nudity]] [[Category:Naturism]] [[Category:Nude beaches|*]] [[Category:Public nudity]] [[Category:Asia-related lists]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Lysons Magna Britannia Vol 4, 1816. Title page.png|thumb|Title page of Volume 4 (Cumberland)]] '''''Magna Britannia, being a concise topographical account of the several counties of Great Britain''''' (to give its full title) was an ambitious [[Topography as the study of place|topographical]] and historical survey published by the [[antiquarian]]s [[Daniel Lysons (antiquarian)|Daniel Lysons]] and his brother [[Samuel Lysons]] in several volumes between 1806 and 1822. It covers the counties of [[Bedfordshire]], [[Berkshire]], [[Buckinghamshire]], [[Cambridgeshire]], [[Cheshire]], [[Cornwall]], [[Cumberland]], [[Derbyshire]], and [[Devon]]. The work was curtailed in 1819 on Samuel Lysons' death.
Unlike other similar works published in the 17th and 18th centuries, ''Magna Britannia'' remains of value today because the Lysons brothers included content on topics such as population, manufacture and commerce. They were also far less preoccupied than many antiquarians with [[coats of arms]] and [[Pedigree chart|pedigrees]], and did not overstate the grandeur of the counties, as local topographers were apt to do.
An earlier work under the same title had been compiled by [[Thomas Cox (topographer)|Thomas Cox]].<ref>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Cox, Thomas}}</ref>
==Volumes== *Volume 1 *[https://archive.org/stream/magnabrittanicab02lyso#page/n5/mode/2up Volume 2, ''Cambridgeshire and the County Palatine of Chester, 1810] *[https://archive.org/stream/magnabrittanicab03lyso#page/n7/mode/2up Volume 3, ''Cornwall'', London, 1814] *[https://archive.org/stream/magnabritanniab01lysogoog#page/n10/mode/2up Volume 4, ''Cumberland'', 1816] *[https://archive.org/stream/magnabrittanicab05lyso#page/n7/mode/2up Volume 5, ''Derbyshire'', 1817] *[https://archive.org/details/magnabrittanicab06lyso Volume 6, ''Devonshire'', 1822]
==See also== *[[William Camden#Britannia|William Camden's ''Britannia'']]
==References== *[[Dictionary of National Biography#Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'']]: entries for Daniel and Samuel Lysons.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/000234457 Digitised volumes] at [[HathiTrust]]. Retrieved 13 March 2015. *[https://archive.org/search.php?query=Magna%20Britannia%20AND%20mediatype%3Atexts Digitised volumes] at [[Internet Archive]]. Retrieved 13 March 2015. *[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/search/series/magna-britannia Digitised volumes of Magna Britannia] at [[British History Online]]. Retrieved 13 March 2015.
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Reference works in the public domain]] [[Category:Books about England]] [[Category:1806 books]] [[Category:1822 books]]
{{Topography-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Melissa Leach | honorific_suffix = {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|CBE|FBA}} | image = Melissa_Leach2014.jpg | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1965|01|05}}{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = British | known_for = | education = | alma_mater = [[SOAS, University of London|School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS)]], University of London
[[Newnham College, Cambridge|Newnham College]], University of Cambridge, UK | employer = | occupation = | religion = | spouse = | children = Four | parents = [[Penelope Leach|Penelope Jane Leach]]; Gerald Leach | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Melissa Leach''', {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|CBE|FBA}} (born 5 January 1965) is a British [[geographer]] and [[Social anthropology|social anthropologist]]. She studies sustainability and development concerns in policy-making and has a focus on the politics of science and technology of Africa. As of 2017 she was the Director of the Institute of Development Studies (IDS) at the [[University of Sussex]]. ==Education== She earned her BA in [[geography]] with [[starred first]] honours at the [[University of Cambridge]], and her MPhil and PhD in [[social anthropology]] from the [[SOAS, University of London|SOAS University of London]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2007/jul/17/highereducationprofile.academicexperts|title=Melissa Leach: Village voice|last=Shepherd|first=Jessica|date=17 July 2007|work=The Guardian|access-date=14 March 2017|issn=0261-3077}} Leach co-founded and directed the [[Economic and Social Research Council|ESRC]] STEPS (Social, Technological and Environmental Pathways to Sustainability) Centre from 2006 to 2014.{{Cite web|url=http://es.unesco.org/node/252673|title=Melissa Leach|website=UNESCO Who's Who of Women Speakers|dead-url=|access-date=21 March 2017}} ==Awards and honours== * 1998: Amaury Talbot Prize of the Royal Anthropological Institute, for best book in African Anthropology, for 'Misreading the African Landscape'.{{Cite web|url=https://www.therai.org.uk/awards/past-awards/amaury-talbot-prize-for-african-anthropology-past-recipients|title=Amaury Talbot Prize for African Anthropology Past Recipients|publisher=Royal Anthropological Institute|dead-url=|access-date=14 March 2017}} * 2012: European Association for the Study of Science and Technology Ziman Prize for public engagement with science, for STEPS Centre 'New Manifesto' initiative. * 2016: ESRC Outstanding International Impact Award for Ebola Response Anthropology Platform (ERAP).{{Cite web|url=http://www.esrc.ac.uk/news-events-and-publications/news/news-items/ebola-crisis-team-wins-award-for-lifesaving-advice/|title=Ebola crisis team wins award for lifesaving advice|date=1 July 2016|website=Economic and Social Research Council|dead-url=|access-date=14 March 2017}} * 2017: Leach was appointed [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the [[2017 Birthday Honours]] for services to the social sciences.{{London Gazette|issue=61962|supp=y|page=B9|date=17 June 2017}} * 2017: In July 2017, she was elected a [[Fellow of the British Academy]] (FBA), the United Kingdom's [[national academy]] for the humanities and social sciences.{{cite web|title=Elections to the British Academy celebrate the diversity of UK research|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/news/elections-british-academy-celebrate-diversity-uk-research|website=British Academy|accessdate=29 July 2017|date=2 July 2017}} ==Membership and professional activities== * Vice-Chair of the Science Committee of Future Earth, steering development of agenda around planetary futures, sustainability and post-2015 development.{{Cite news|url=http://www.futureearth.org/science-committee|title=Science Committee|work=Future Earth|access-date=14 March 2017|language=en}} * Member of the International Panel of Experts on Sustainable Food Systems (IPES-Food).{{Cite web|url=http://www.ipes-food.org/members|title=Expert Panel – IPES food|website=International Panel of Experts on Sustainable Food Systems|dead-url=|access-date=14 March 2017}} * Lead author of the UN Women 2014 World Survey on the Role of Women in Development on gender equality and sustainable development.{{Cite news|url=http://www.unwomen.org/en/digital-library/publications/2016/8/discussion-paper-series-gender-equality-and-sustainable-development|title=Gender Equality and Sustainable Development: A Pathways Approach|year=2016|work=UN Women|access-date=14 March 2017|dead-url=|language=en}} * Co-Leader, ISSC World Social Science Report 2016 on Inequalities and Social justice.{{cite web|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002458/245825e.pdf|format=PDF|date=2016 |title= Challenging Inequalities: Pathways to a Just World|website=Unesdoc.unesco.org|accessdate=9 June 2018}} * Trustee, Malaria Consortium * Advisory Board member, ESRC ‘Nexus Network: New connections in food, energy, water and the environment’.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenexusnetwork.org/about/advisory-group/|title=Advisory Group|date=8 February 2018|website=Thenexusnetwork.org|accessdate=9 June 2018}} * UK Scientific Advisory Group on Emergencies (SAGE) Ebola, 2014 – 15.{{cite web|url=https://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201516/cmselect/cmsctech/469/46906.htm|title=House of Commons - Science in emergencies: UK lessons from Ebola - Science and Technology Committee|website=Publications.parliament.uk|accessdate=9 June 2018}} ==Selected publications== * Leach, M. and Scoones, I. eds., 2015. ''Carbon conflicts and forest landscapes in Africa''. Routledge. * Leach, M., 2015. ''The Ebola Crisis and Post‐2015 Development''. Journal of International Development, 27(6), pp. 816–834. * Leach, M., Raworth, K. and Rockström, J., 2013. ''Between social and planetary boundaries: Navigating pathways in the safe and just space for humanity''. World social science report, 2013, pp. 84–89. * Fairhead, J., Leach, M. and Scoones, I., 2012. ''Green Grabbing: a new appropriation of nature?''. Journal of Peasant Studies, 39(2), pp. 237–261. * Leach, M., Scoones, I. and Wynne, B., 2005. ''Science and citizens: globalisation and the challenge of engagement'' (Vol. 2). Zed Books. * Fairhead, J. and M. Leach, 1996, ''Misreading the African landscape: society and ecology in a forest-Savanna mosaic''. Cambridge and New York: Cambridge University Press. * Leach, M., Mearns, R. and Scoones, I., 1999. ''Environmental entitlements: dynamics and institutions in community-based natural resource management''. World development, 27(2), pp. 225–247. * Leach, M. and Mearns, R., 1996. ''Environmental change and policy. The Lie of the Land: challenging received wisdom on the African environment''. Oxford: James Currey, pp. 1–33. * Leach, M. and R. Mearns, 1996, ''The Lie of the land: Challenging received wisdom on the African environment''. Oxford: James Currey Publishers Ltd. and New York: Heinemann * Leach, M., 1994, ''Rainforest relations: Gender and resource use among the Mende of Gola, Sierra Leone''. Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press and Washington: Smithsonian Institution ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.ids.ac.uk/person/melissa-leach Melissa Leach] on the Institute of Development Studies website * [http://www.sussex.ac.uk/profiles/1575 Prof Melissa Leach] on the University of Sussex website * [https://www.bond.org.uk/person/professor-melissa-leach Professor Melissa Leach] on the Bond website {{FBA 2017|state=expanded}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Leach, Melissa}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of SOAS, University of London]] [[Category:Alumni of Newnham College, Cambridge]] [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:British geographers]] [[Category:British anthropologists]] [[Category:Fellows of the British Academy]]

A '''P-code''', short for '''Place code''', is a kind of [[Address (geography)|addressing system]] used mostly by emergency response teams. It provides unique identifiers to thousands of locations and administrative units in a humanitarian operation.The p-codes are represented by combinations of letters and/or numbers to identify a specific location or feature on a map or within a database. These codes provide a systematic means of linking data to an unambiguous location. Any information that is tagged with P-codes can be combined and analyzed with any other p-coded data. The p-codes for a country can be found in the Common Operational Datasets, which are standard geographic references for the humanitarian community provided by [http://cod/humanitarianresponse/info/ UN OCHA]:
==References== *[https://cod.humanitarianresponse.info/system/files/documents/files/PcodeFlyer_Generic.pdf/ P-code Flyer] *[https://cod.humanitarianresponse.info/documentation/ Guidance for P-codes, Humanitarian Response.info]

{{Infobox ancient site | name = Qadamgah | native_name = قدمگاه | native_name_lang = fa | alternate_name = Chasht-Khor | image = File:Qadamgah Water monument.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Qadamgah monument | map = | map_type = Iran | map_alt = | map_caption = | map_size = | altitude_m = <!-- Enter a number for altitude in meters (m) --> | altitude_ref = | relief = | coordinates = {{Coord|29|44|2.508|N|53|12|44.0568|E|display=inline,title}} | map_dot_label = | location = [[Kuh-e Rahmat]] mountain, north of [[Chasht Khvor]] village, [[Arsanjan County]], [[Fars Province]], [[Iran]] | region = | type = Monument of probable cultic function | part_of = | length = {{convert|20.30|m}} | width = {{convert|13.50|m}} | area = | volume = | diameter = | circumference = | height = {{convert|16.50|m}} | builder = | material = | built = | abandoned = | epochs = [[Achaemenid Empire|Achaemenid]] or post-Achaemenid | cultures = [[Greater Iran|Persian]] | dependency_of = | occupants = | event = | discovered = 1881 | excavations = None | archaeologists = | condition = Decaying | ownership = | management = [[Cultural Heritage, Handicrafts and Tourism Organization of Iran]] | public_access = yes | other_designation = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | architectural_styles = [[Achaemenid architecture|Achaemenid]] | architectural_details = | notes = }}
'''Qadamgah''' or '''Chasht-Khor''' is a (post)-[[Achaemenid Empire|Achaemenid]] [[rock-cut architecture|rock-cut]] monument at the southeastern part of the [[Kuh-e Rahmat]] mountain in [[Fars Province]] of [[Iran]], about 40 km south of [[Persepolis]]. It consists of three platforms with rear walls and staircases, and features cavities on the back wall and a now-dry spring and pond at the bottom. Its function has been a matter of debate, with latest research pointing to a religious function related to the holy element [[Aban|Water]].
==Name== ''Qadamgah'', also transliterated as ''Kadam Gah'' ({{lang-fa|قدمگاه}} ''Qadamgāh'', {{IPA-fa|ɢædæmˈgɒːh}}), is the modern Persian word for "footprint". Another local name is ''Qadamgāh-e Ali'' ({{lang|fa|قدمگاه علی}}, literally "the footprint of [[Ali]]").<ref name="iranica" /> The structure is also called ''Īvān-e Qadmgāh'' ({{lang|fa|ایوان قدمگاه}}, literally "the [[iwan]] of Qadamgah").
Another name is ''Chāsht-Khār'' ({{lang|fa|چاشت خوار}} or {{lang|fa|چاشتخوار}} {{IPA-fa|t͡ʃʰɒːʃtˈxɒːɾ|}}), or ''Chāsht-Khor'' ({{lang|fa|چاشت خور}} or {{lang|fa|چاشتخور}} {{IPA-fa|t͡ʃʰɒːʃtˈxoɾ|}}), which is also the name of [[Chasht Khor|the village nearby]].<ref name=parstourguides />
==Studies, description, and function== {{external media | float = left | width = 210px | image1 = [http://www.iranicaonline.org/uploads/files/qadamgah/qadamgah-fig2a.jpg Plan of Qadamgah by Wells (a)] | image2 = [http://www.iranicaonline.org/uploads/files/qadamgah/qadamgah-fig2b.jpg Plan of Qadamgah by Wells (b)] }}
The monument was first discovered by Capt. H. L. Wells (from the [[Royal Engineers]]) in 1881 who published a drawing of the plan and section of it, but did not describe it.<ref name="iranica" /> The structure and its purpose was later discussed by [[Forsat-od-Dowla Shirazi|Forsat-od-Dowleh]] (1854–1920), [[Louis Vanden Berghe]] (1954), [[Giorgio Gullini]] (1964), [[Mohammad Taqi Mostafavi]] (1964), Calmeyer (1975), [[Rémy Boucharlat]] (1979), Kleiss (1993), and Jean-Claude Bessac (2007).<ref name=parstourguides>{{cite web|last1=حسینی|first1=سید علیمحمد|title=◄بنای صخره‌ای قدمگاه (چاشت خور) ارسنجان|url=http://www.parstourguides.ir/index.php/-association-articles/item/257-%E2%97%84%D8%A8%D9%86%D8%A7%DB%8C-%D8%B5%D8%AE%D8%B1%D9%87%E2%80%8C%D8%A7%DB%8C-%D9%82%D8%AF%D9%85%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%87-%DA%86%D8%A7%D8%B4%D8%AA-%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%B3%D9%86%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86|website=www.parstourguides.ir|publisher=انجمن صنفی راهنمایان ایرانگردی و جهانگردی استان فارس|accessdate=14 July 2017|language=fa-ir}}</ref> <!-- Is this a reference to [[Qadamgah, Marvdasht]]? According to Paul Schwartz, the place name ''Ḥafr'' ({{lang|ar|حفر}}) mentioned by [[Ibn Khordadbeh]] may refer to Qadamgah.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Schwatz|first1=Paul|title=Jughrafiya-yi Tarikhi-i Fars|date=1372 [1993]|publisher=[[Society for the National Heritage of Iran|Anjuman-i Asar va Mafakhir-i Farhangi]]|location=Tehran|page=238|url=http://www.noorlib.ir/View/fa/Book/BookView/Image/6788/1/238|accessdate=14 July 2017|language=fa}}</ref> -->
[[File:Qadamgah mortise (3746636089).jpg|thumb|upright|left|The right-hand staircase and one of the holes (in foreground)]] The structure has been built by cutting two deep [[Terrace (building)|terraces]] vertically from the top of the rocky [[limestone]] slope, forming three superimposed platforms with vertical rear walls. The monument lacks any built structures. Underneath the lower terrace there has been a now-dry spring feeding a pool which overlooked the monument. The terraces are {{convert|13.50|m}} wide. The lower terrace is {{convert|3|m}} above the ground. The upper terrace, which is {{convert|4.25|m}} higher, is linked to the lower one by two rock-cut staircases on the sides. Three rows of five shallow cavities have been cut in rectangular form into the back wall above the upper terrace. Several shallow, hemispherical holes are also cut along the edge of the upper terrace.<ref name="iranica">{{cite web|last1=Boucharlat|first1=R.|title=QADAMGĀH|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/qadamgah|website=[[Encyclopaedia Iranica|Encyclopædia Iranica Online]]|accessdate=14 July 2017|language=en|date=19 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Qadamgah|url=http://www.livius.org/articles/place/qadamgah/|website=Livius|accessdate=14 July 2017|language=en}}</ref>
The structure dates back to the [[Achaemenid Empire|Achaemenid]] or post-Achaemenid period. Several hypotheses have been proposed for its function, including an unfinished Royal tomb (it is compared to the [[Persepolis#Tombs|two tombs near Persepolis]]; the construction would have been abandoned like the so-called "unfinished tomb of Darius III" at Persepolis South), a funerary function (with the cavities functioning as a [[astodan|place for bones (''astōdān'')]]), or a cultural function.<ref name="iranica" /> Later observations suggest the work was finished, and the cavities were likely covered with hypothetical stone slabs (which may have contained inscriptions or reliefs for aesthetic purposes). Latest research by Jean-Claude Bessac favors a "cultic function related to water" (''[[Aban]]'') and the presence of the spring and the pool, and dismisses the funerary function. This would make Qadamgah a unique Achaemenid cultic place known to the date.<ref name="iranica" /><ref name=Bessac>{{cite journal|last1=Bessac|first1=J.-C.|title=Étude technique et interprétations du monument rupestre de Qadamgah (Fars)|journal=Iranica Antiqua|date=1 January 2007|volume=42|pages=185–206|doi=10.2143/IA.42.0.2017875|url=http://poj.peeters-leuven.be/content.php?id=2017875&url=article}}</ref> There are also cuneiform clay-tablets in the [[Persepolis Administrative Archives]] with possible references to this site.<ref>[http://ganj.irandoc.ac.ir/articles/678585 "بررسی محوطه هخامنشی قدمگاه ارسنجان (فارس) و مقایسه آن محوطه های همزمان همان منطقه"], thesis</ref><ref name="iranica" />
The monument is fragile and is slowly decaying. The only published drawing of the plan and section of the monument is that of H. L. Wells. Rémy Boucharlat in ''[[Encyclopædia Iranica]]'' advises "a complete and careful survey ... and some excavation at its foot".<ref name="iranica" />
==See also== {{Commons category|Qadamgah (Achaemenid monument)}} * [[Temple of Anahita]] * [[Anahita]] * [[Mithra]] * [[Naqsh-e Rostam]] * [[Pasargadae]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:1881 archaeological discoveries]] [[Category:Achaemenid architecture]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in Iran]] [[Category:Archaeology of the Achaemenid Empire]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Fars Province]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Fars Province]] [[Category:Burial monuments and structures]] [[Category:Religious places]] [[Category:Places of worship in Iran]] [[Category:Water and religion]] [[Category:Anahita]] [[Category:Zoroastrianism]] [[Category:Arsanjan County| ]]

revision.comment: /* top */clean up punctuation and spacing issues, primarily spacing around commas, replaced: , → , using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Ray Watters | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1928 | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = New Zealand | other_names = | occupation = Geographer | years_active = | known_for = Conducted interdisciplinary studies and projects | notable_works = }} '''Raymond Frederick''' '''Watters''' (born 1928) is a New Zealand [[geographer]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ray Watters, School of Geography, Environment and Earth Sciences, Victoria University of Wellington|url=http://www.victoria.ac.nz/sgees/about/staff/ray-watters|website=Victoria University of Wellington|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> He has conducted interdisciplinary studies and projects for [[UN]] agencies, British Overseas Development Administration, NZ Aid and governments of a number of developing countries including [[Solomon Islands]], [[Kiribati]], [[Tuvalu]], [[Mexico]], [[Venezuela]], [[Peru]] and [[Papua New Guinea]].
In 2009 he was honoured with the Distinguished [[New Zealand Geography Award]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Distinguished New Zealand Geographer|url=http://www.nzgs.co.nz/awards/distinguished-new-zealand-geographer}}</ref>
He specialises in rural development and social change in the developing world, especially in [[Oceania]] (South Pacific), [[Latin America]] and [[Guizhou]] in south-west [[China]]. He has also extensively studied shifting agriculture in the hot, wet tropics, human geography and development problems in tribal and peasant societies at micro, meso and macro levels, and the nature of peasantry in the Southern [[Andes]], [[Peru]]. Many studies involved geographic, historical, anthropological and economic analyses or synthesis, as well as village fieldwork.
After attaining a bachelor of arts and master of arts (honours) from [[University of Auckland|Auckland]] and [[Victoria University College]]s respectively, he completed a Ph.D. at the [[London School of Economics]] in 1956 for a thesis on the historical geography of Samoa.<ref>{{cite web|title=Distinguished New Zealand Geography Award: Professor Ray Watters|url=https://www.academia.edu/27118152/Distinguished_New_Zealand_Geography_Award_Professor_Ray_Watters|website=www.academia.edu|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> He taught at Victoria University of Wellington for 38 years, giving courses on Latin America, historical geography, the Pacific and Chinese peasantry.
Watters led research projects on the Solomon Islands, resulting in three Ph.Ds and four major reports; the [[Gilbert and Ellice Islands]] project, yielding three Ph.Ds and six major reports and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs project on Small Island States (with Geoff Bertram),<ref>{{cite web|title=New Zealand and its Small Island Neighbours: A Review of New Zealand Policy Toward the Cook Islands, Niue, Tokelau, Kiribati and Tuvalu|url=http://igps.victoria.ac.nz/publications/people/show/206|website=igps.victoria.ac.nz}}</ref> out of which came the MIRAB (migration, remittance, foreign aid, public bureaucracy) model.<ref>{{cite web|title=The MIRAB Model of Small Island Economies in the Pacific and their Security Issues: A Draft|url=https://www.academia.edu/26735014/The_MIRAB_Model_of_Small_Island_Economies_in_the_Pacific_and_their_Security_Issues_A_Draft_SOCIAL_ECONOMICS_POLICY_AND_DEVELOPMENT_WP_57_|website=www.academia.edu|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref>
==Published works==
* ''Land and Society in New Zealand: Essays in Historical Geography''<ref>{{cite book|title=Land and society in New Zealand; essays in historical geography|date=1965|publisher=A. H. & A. W. Reed|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/land-and-society-in-new-zealand-essays-in-historical-geography/oclc/450574|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref> * ''Koro, Economic Development and Social Change in Fiji''<ref>{{cite journal|title=KORO. ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND SOCIAL CHANGE IN FIJI|journal=New Zealand Geographer|date=October 1972|volume=28|issue=2|doi=10.1111/j.1745-7939.1972.tb01188.x|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1745-7939.1972.tb01188.x/abstract}}</ref> * ''Shifting Cultivation in Latin America''<ref name="Watters1971">{{cite book|author=Raymond Frederick Watters|title=Shifting cultivation in Latin America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kA9JAAAAMAAJ|date=November 1971|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization}}</ref> * With W. H. GEDDES, ANNE CHAMBERS, BETSY SEWELL, ROGER LAWRENCE – ''Atoll Economy: Social Change in Kiribati and Tuvalu''<ref>{{cite journal|title=Atoll Economy: Social Change in Kiribati and Tuvalu|journal=American Ethnologist|date=February 1985|volume=12|issue=1|doi=10.1525/ae.1985.12.1.02a00280|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1525/ae.1985.12.1.02a00280/abstract|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref> * With I. G. Bertram – ''New Zealand and its Small island Neighbours.'' A report of NZ policy towards the Cook Islands, Niue, Tokelau, Kiribati and Tuvalu<ref>{{cite web|title=New Zealand and its Small Island Neighbours: A Review of New Zealand Policy Toward the Cook Islands, Niue, Tokelau, Kiribati and Tuvalu|url=http://researcharchive.vuw.ac.nz/xmlui/handle/10063/2577|website=researcharchive.vuw.ac.nz/}}</ref> * ''Poverty and Peasantry in Peru's Southern Andes, 1963–90''<ref>{{cite book|last1=Watters|first1=Ray|title=Poverty and Peasantry in Peru's Southern Andes|date=1994|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=0-333-55023-4|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?hl=en&lr=&id=ifOxCwAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PR12&dq=Poverty+and+Peasantry+in+Peru%27s+Southern+Andes,&ots=vFuJb7KdDu&sig=mJ5ZrxdZmQ4GjSKuPZg28Ue4vc0#v=onepage&q=Poverty%20and%20Peasantry%20in%20Peru%27s%20Southern%20Andes%2C&f=false}}</ref> * With T. G. McGee – ''Asia Pacific. New Geographies of the Pacific Rim''<ref name="WattersMcGee1997">{{cite book|author1=Raymond Frederick Watters|author2=T. G. McGee|author3=Ginny Sullivan|title=Asia-Pacific: New Geographies of the Pacific Rim|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=doA_2x2DhWgC|year=1997|publisher=UBC Press|isbn=978-0-7748-0647-3}}</ref> * ''Journeys Towards Progress: Essays of a Geographer on Development and Change in Oceania''<ref>{{cite journal|title=Journeys Towards Progress. Essays of a Geographer on Development and Change in Oceania|journal=New Zealand Geographer|date=August 2010|volume=66|issue=2|doi=10.1111/j.1745-7939.2010.01183_5.x|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1745-7939.2010.01183_5.x/abstract}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Redirect|Abri}} {{About|the geological formation|landslip protection|Rock shed}} [[File:Indian Cave.jpg|thumb|The rock shelter for which [[Indian Cave State Park]] is named.]] [[Image:Rock shelter Papula.jpg|thumb|Rock shelter in the [[Little Carpathians]]]] A '''rock shelter''' — also '''rockhouse''', '''crepuscular cave''', '''bluff shelter''', or '''abri''' — is a shallow [[cave]]-like opening at the base of a bluff or [[cliff]]. In contrast to [[solutional cave|solutional cave (karst) caves]], which are often many miles long, rock shelters are almost always modest in size and extent. ==Formation== Rock shelters form because a [[Rock (geology)|rock]] stratum such as sandstone that is resistant to [[erosion]] and [[weathering]] has formed a cliff or bluff, but a softer stratum, more subject to erosion and weathering, lies just below the resistant stratum, and thus undercuts the cliff. In arid areas, [[wind]] erosion (eolian erosion) can be an important factor in rockhouse formation. In most humid areas, the most important factor in rockhouse formation is [[frost weathering|frost spalling]], where the softer, more porous rock underneath is pushed off, tiny pieces at a time, by frost expansion from water frozen in the pores. Erosion from moving water is seldom a significant factor. Many rock shelters are found under [[waterfalls]]. File:Rock shelter formation by frost weathering.svg|By [[frost weathering]] File:Rock shelter formation by karst gallery cutting.svg|By cutting a [[karst]] gallery File:Rock shelter formation by river erosion.svg|By [[river erosion]] ==Human habitat== [[File:Shepherds' rock shelter, Lahaul.jpg|thumb|Shepherds' rock shelter in [[Lahaul]], India]] Rock shelters are often important [[archaeology|archaeologically]]. Because rock shelters form natural shelters from the weather, prehistoric humans often used them as living-places, and left behind debris, tools, and other [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifacts]]. In mountainous areas the shelters can also be important for [[Mountaineering|mountaineers]]. [[Transhumant]] nomads, people who move with their livestock - often from lower permanent winter residences in the valleys to higher summer pastures - frequently build semi-permanent camps, often of rocks. In western [[Connecticut]] and eastern [[New York (state)|New York]], many rock shelters are known by the [[colloquialism]] "leatherman caves",[http://www.ctmuseumquest.com/?page_id=6343 CT Museum: Leatherman Caves] as they were inhabited by the [[Leatherman (vagabond)|Leatherman]] over three decades in the late 19th century. ==Unique vegetation== The [[Minuartia cumberlandensis|Cumberland stitchwort]] (''Minuartia cumberlandensis'') is an endangered species of plant which is found only in rock shelters in Kentucky and Tennessee.[http://www.centerforplantconservation.org/collection/cpc_viewprofile.asp?CPCNum=13821 Center for Plant Conservation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215120249/http://centerforplantconservation.org/Collection/CPC_ViewProfile.asp?CPCNum=13821 |date=2010-12-15 }} [[Image: turtleheadcave.jpg|right|thumb|Rock shelter at
[[Strouds Run State Park]]]] ==See also== * [[Gatecliff Rockshelter]] * [[Kinlock Shelter]] * [[Mesa Verde]] * [[Overhang (architecture)]] * [[Roc-aux-Sorciers]] * [[Rock shed]] * [[Shelter Rock (North Hills, New York)]] * [[Walnut Canyon]] {{commonscat|Rock shelters}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * Acosta ''et al''., 2018. Climate change and peopling of the Neotropics during the Pleistocene-Holocene transition. Boletín de la Sociedad Geológica Mexicana. http://boletinsgm.igeolcu.unam.mx/bsgm/index.php/component/content/article/368-sitio/articulos/cuarta-epoca/7001/1857-7001-1-acosta {{Prehistoric technology| state=expanded}} [[Category:Rock shelters| ]] [[Category:Caves]] {{topography-stub}}

page.title: Satish Dhawan Space Centre Third Launch Pad

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Use Indian English|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox launch pad | image = | caption = | imsize = | name = Third Launch Pad | site = [[Satish Dhawan Space Centre]] | location = [[Sriharikota]] | short = TLP | operator = {{Flag icon|India}} [[Indian Space Research Organisation|ISRO]] | paddetails = Human Space Flight Rated {{Infobox launch pad/pad | status = Under construction | launches = 0 | first = 2020 (planned) | last = | rockets = [[Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle|PSLV]]
[[Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle|GSLV]]
[[Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle Mk III|GSLV Mk.III]]
[[Unified Modular Launch Vehicle|UMLV]]
[[Avatar (spacecraft)|Avatar RLV]] }} }} The '''Third Launch Pad''' (TLP) of the [[Satish Dhawan Space Centre]] is an under development [[rocket launch site]] in [[Sriharikota]], India. When the launch pad will be completely built, it will be the third launch pad in the [[Satish Dhawan Space Centre]], the other two being [[Satish Dhawan Space Centre First Launch Pad|First Launch Pad]] and the [[Satish Dhawan Space Centre Second Launch Pad|Second Launch Pad]]. The launch of India's first [[List of crewed spacecraft|crewed orbital spacecraft]] "[[Gaganyaan]]" is scheduled to be launch from the third launch pad before 2022{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/isro-setting-up-launch-pad-for-gaganyaan-mission/article25010147.ece|title=ISRO setting up launch pad for Gaganyaan mission|last=Peri|first=Dinakar|date=2018-09-21|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-09-22|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}. == Usage == This launch pad is intended to be used for future Indian rockets like the [[Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle Mk III]] and [[Avatar (spacecraft)|Avatar RLV]] (Avatar Reusable Launch Vehicle) as well as the older ones like [[Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle]] and [[Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle]].{{cite news | url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-07-01/india/32494121_1_sriharikota-gslv-mk-iii-heavier-satellites | title=Isro to build third launchpad at Sriharikota | work=[[Press Trust of India|PTI]] | date=1 July 2012 | agency=[[Times of India]] | accessdate=8 June 2013}} This is the launch pad which will be used for the [[Indian human spaceflight programme]] as well as for India's first manned space mission.{{cite news | url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/ISRO+to+begin+process+for+Human+Space+Flight+Mission/1/81067.html | title=ISRO to begin process for Human Space Flight Mission | work=[[Press Trust of India|PTI]] | date=26 January 2010 | agency=[[India Today]] | accessdate=8 June 2013 | location=Hyderabad}} One of the main reasons of building this launch pad is that it will increase the frequency of orbital launches by ISRO.{{cite news | url=http://www.indiandefence.com/forums/strategic-geopolitical-issues/19518-isro-build-third-launch-pad-spaceport.html | title=ISRO To Build A Third Launch Pad at Spaceport | work=Indiadefence.com | date=2 June 2012 | accessdate=8 June 2013}} == Facilities == Several facilities have been proposed to be built at the Third Launch Pad. They include a vehicle assembly building, mobile pedestals, umbilical towers, emergency exits, ground escape system, crew ingress and egress systems, safety bunkers, material handling equipment and related electrical systems.This section contains public domain text which were published by the [[Press Trust of India]]. == Status == Construction of the launch pad started in September 2012.{{cite news | url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/63143/F | title=3rd launch pad to be built | work=[[Deccan Herald]] | date=2 June 2012 | accessdate=8 June 2013 | author=Chandrashekar, Nandini | location=Bangalore}} The total cost of the new launch pad is estimated to be {{INRConvert|120|b}}. == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{Satish Dhawan Space Centre}} {{Indian space programme}} [[Category:Rocket launch sites]] [[Category:Space programme of India]] [[Category:Satish Dhawan Space Centre]]

page.title: School of Geography, University of Leeds

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Geography education]]; added [[Category:Geography education in the United Kingdom]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{notability|date=June 2017}} {{primary sources|date=June 2017}} '''The School of Geography''' is part of the Faculty of Environment at [[The University of Leeds]] based in the [[UK]].
== History == [[The University of Leeds]] was one of the earliest British universities to establish a school of [[geography]] in 1919. Various types of geography, including commercial geography, had been taught at the Yorkshire College (which preceded the University of Leeds) and in the university [[economics]] department before 1919. This reflects an earlier and broader European interest in the use of geographical knowledge as an aid to national and international trade. The early, inter-war years were characterized by small numbers of staff and honours students, very few research students, and limited resources and range of topics covered. The school has generally expanded over the years and in 2011 has about 70 members of academic staff and a large number of research students studying a broad spectrum of geographical topics.
A celebrated historical geographer, [[Robin Butlin]] has developed a history of the school and presented this twice at anniversary celebrations. Hopefully some of this material will become linked here in due course. (Unfortunately neither of these presentations were video recorded.)
In the recent past the school was the hub of a major [[glaciology]] research group headed by [[Tavi Murray]] now based at the University of Swansea.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://ralph.swan.ac.uk/glaciology/people/tmurray/ | title = Professor Tavi Murray's Web Page | accessdate = 2011-05-24 }}</ref>
Various notable people have worked or studied in the school including: [[Danny Dorling]] and [[Stan Openshaw]]; [[Martine Croxall]] and [[Piers Sellers]]. Other notable people are still based there albeit in an emeritus capacity including [[Robin Butlin]], [[Mike Kirkby]] and [[Phil Rees (academic)|Phil Rees]].
== Teaching == One of the larger geography departments in the UK, with over 600 single honours undergraduate students, 55 masters students and 60 research postgraduate students in 2011. It offers a range of BA and BSc [[undergraduate]] programmes some offered in conjunction with other university departments, including, the Institute for Transport Studies <ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.its.leeds.ac.uk/ | title = Institute for Transport Studies Web Site | accessdate = 2011-05-24 }}</ref> and the School of Earth and Environment.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.environment.leeds.ac.uk/see/ | title = School of Earth and Environment Web Site | accessdate = 2011-05-24 }}</ref> A range of geography elective modules are available for students from any discipline undertaking courses at Leeds.
It offers a number of MA, MSc and MRes courses, including both vocationally orientated and research-focused courses. Many of these courses are also available as Postgraduate Diploma (PGDip) or Postgraduate Certificate (PGCert) courses and are also available under the part-time study scheme. In addition to face-to-face taught programmes, the GIS programme is available as a flexible, part-time, on-line [[distance learning]] programme in which students can structure their study around other commitments.
PhD research at the school attracts students from around the world. The [[postgraduate]] research community is broadly divided among the five research clusters. Each of these maintain a list of topics they are interested in supervising.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.geog.leeds.ac.uk/study/phd/topics.html |title = School of Geography PhD Topics Web Page |accessdate = 2011-05-24 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110613232839/http://www.geog.leeds.ac.uk/study/phd/topics.html |archivedate = 2011-06-13 |df = }}</ref> In addition to those listed, the school welcomes applications from prospective students that detail their own ideas for research in a proposal form.
== Research == Its aim is to be at the forefront of research, helping to tackle major social, political and environmental challenges associated with global change.
In the 2008 [[Research Assessment Exercise|RAE exercise]], it was ranked in the top six geography departments in the UK and awarded an 'Excellent' grading by [[HEFCE]] for the quality of its teaching, which is research-led. 70% of its research activity was judged to be 'internationally leading' or 'internationally excellent'.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.geog.leeds.ac.uk/ | title = School of Geography, University of Leeds Home Web Page | accessdate = 2011-06-08 }}</ref>
It currently has five research clusters about which the school administration and teaching is organised: * The Ecology and Global Change research cluster is active in [[tropical ecology]], [[paleogeography]], and global scale modelling research.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.geog.leeds.ac.uk/research/eco.html | title = School of Geography, University of Leeds Ecology and Global Change Research Cluster Web Page | accessdate = 2011-06-08 }}</ref> * The Centre for Spatial Analysis and Policy (CSAP) research cluster is active in [[retail geography]], [[geodemographics]], [[demography|demographic modelling]], [[wilderness]], and city and regional planning research.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.geog.leeds.ac.uk/research/csap.html | title = School of Geography, University of Leeds Centre for Spatial Analysis and Policy (CSAP) Research Cluster Web Page | accessdate = 2011-06-08 }}</ref> * The River Basin Processes and Management research cluster is active in peatland, uplands, stream ecology, and glacial outburst flood research.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.geog.leeds.ac.uk/research/ribpram.html | title = School of Geography, University of Leeds River Basin Processes and Management Research Cluster Web Page | accessdate = 2011-06-08 }}</ref> * The Cities and Social Justice research cluster is active in [[neoliberal]], consumption, [[sustainability]] and [[activism]] research <ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.geog.leeds.ac.uk/research/justice.html | title = School of Geography, University of Leeds Cities and Social Justice Research Cluster Web Page | accessdate = 2011-06-08 }}</ref> * The Citizenship and Belonging research cluster is active in [[citizenship]], [[diaspora]], [[ethnicity]], and [[Human sexuality|sexuality]] research <ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.geog.leeds.ac.uk/research/citizens.html | title = School of Geography, University of Leeds Citizenship and Belonging Research Cluster Web Page | accessdate = 2011-06-08 }}</ref>
On-going research is examining major world cities and some of the remotest places on earth including the [[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]] and within the depths of the [[tropical rainforest]].
Water@leeds is a multimillion-pound university centre led by Joseph Holden.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.wateratleeds.org/ | title = The University of Leeds Water Research Centre Web Site | accessdate = 2011-06-08 }}</ref>
Global alliances of forest researchers in South America (RAINFOR) <ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.geog.leeds.ac.uk/projects/rainfor/ | title = School of Geography, University of Leeds RAINFOR Home Web Page | accessdate = 2011-06-08 }}</ref> and in Africa (AfriTRON) <ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.geog.leeds.ac.uk/projects/afritron/ |title = School of Geography, University of Leeds AfriTRON Project Web Page |accessdate = 2011-06-08 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110613232823/http://www.geog.leeds.ac.uk/projects/afritron/ |archivedate = 2011-06-13 |df = }}</ref> are led by Oliver Phillips and Simon Lewis.
The spirit of [[Stan Openshaw]] lives on in the school with the flame carried by those members of the [[Centre for Computational Geography]] (CCG) - an [[inter-disciplinary]] university research centre concerned with the development and application of tools for analysis, [[Information visualization|visualisation]] and modelling geographical [[systems]]. Set up with £8 thousand in 1993, the CCG sustains itself via collaboration on a diverse range of research projects and is directed by Andy Evans.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ccg.leeds.ac.uk/ | title = Centre for Computational Geography, University of Leeds Home Web Page | accessdate = 2011-06-08 }}</ref>
Facilities at the school include a suite of teaching and research laboratories dedicated to [[soil]], [[water]] and [[pollen]] research. There are field equipment stores, cold rooms and [[DEFRA]] approved soil rooms. For work in the field, the school has a 110 Land Rover Defender and a Skoda 4x4 estate vehicle. To support their [[GIS]] and computing activities they have a 24-hour cluster with provision for 25 students. The school has a range or audio visual equipment available to hire.
== Staff == There are around 70 academic and research staff, 60 research postgraduate students and a team of professional support staff in 2011. The current Head of School is David Bell who took up post in August 2012. David succeeded Gill Valentine. Previous incumbents include Gill Valentine, Adrian McDonald, Graham Clarke, John Stillwell, [[Phil Rees (academic)|Phil Rees]], [[Mike Kirkby]] and [[Alan Wilson (academic)|Alan Wilson]].
== Alumni == Alumni include: [[Piers Sellers]], NASA astronaut; [[Simon Rix]], bassist of Leeds-based band the [[Kaiser Chiefs]]; [[Jonathan Hammond (sport shooter)|Jon Hammond]], gold, silver and bronze medal winner in the men's 50m shooting at the [[2010 Commonwealth Games]] in Delhi, [[Martine Croxall]], BBC journalist and presenter and the Most Reverend [[Alan Harper (archbishop)|Alan Harper]], Archbishop of Armagh (appointed an OBE for services to conservation).
The School keeps in touch with alumni through the Alumni Newsletter, Facebook and the School of Geography website.
Graduates are known to have gone on to find positions in the following areas: environmental management, management and consultancy, GIS, government and NGOs, financial services and further study.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.geog.leeds.ac.uk School of Geography website] {{Geography topics |state=autocollapse}} {{University of Leeds}}
{{coord|53.8047|N|1.5556|W|source:wikidata|display=title}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:School Of Geography, University Of Leeds}} [[Category:University of Leeds]] [[Category:Geography organizations]] [[Category:Geography education in the United Kingdom]]
